wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

wb:indicator.wb:name: CO2 emissions (kg per 2005 PPP $ of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Carbon dioxide emissions are those stemming from the burning of fossil fuels and the manufacture of cement. They include carbon dioxide produced during consumption of solid, liquid, and gas fuels and gas flaring.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

wb:indicator.wb:name: CO2 emissions from solid fuel consumption (thousand metric tons)
CO2 emissions from solid fuel consumption (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Carbon dioxide emissions from solid fuel consumption refer mainly to emissions from use of coal as an energy source.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Environmental Sciences Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Tennessee, United States.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other greenhouse gas emissions, HFC, PFC and SF6 (thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other greenhouse gas emissions are by-product emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural methane emissions (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural methane emissions are emissions from animals, animal waste, rice production, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savannah burning.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Energy related methane emissions (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Industrial methane emissions are emissions from the handling, transmission, and combustion of fossil fuels and biofuels.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Methane emissions (kt of CO2 equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Methane emissions are those stemming from human activities such as agriculture and from industrial methane production.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Resources Institute.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural nitrous oxide emissions (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural nitrous oxide emissions are emissions produced through fertilizer use (synthetic and animal manure), animal waste management, agricultural waste burning (nonenergy, on-site), and savannah burning.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Energy related nitrous oxide emissions (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Industrial nitrous oxide emissions are emissions produced during the manufacturing of adipic acid and nitric acid.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nitrous oxide emissions (thousand metric tons of CO2 equivalent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nitrous oxide emissions are emissions from agricultural biomass burning, industrial activities, and livestock management.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Energy Agency.

wb:indicator.wb:name: PM10, country level (micrograms per cubic meter)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Particulate matter concentrations refer to fine suspended particulates less than 10 microns in diameter (PM10) that are capable of penetrating deep into the respiratory tract and causing significant health damage. Data for countries and aggregates for regions and income groups are urban-population weighted PM10 levels in residential areas of cities with more than 100,000 residents. The estimates represent the average annual exposure level of the average urban resident to outdoor particulate matter. The state of a country's technology and pollution controls is an important determinant of particulate matter concentrations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Kiren Dev Pandey, David Wheeler, Bart Ostro, Uwe Deichmann, Kirk Hamilton, and Katherine Bolt. "Ambient Particulate Matter Concentrations in Residential and Pollution Hotspot Areas of World Cities: New Estimates Based on the Global Model of Ambient Particulates (GMAPS)," World Bank, Development Research Group and Environment Department (2006).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Bird species, threatened
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Birds are listed for countries included within their breeding or wintering ranges. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Bird species, total known
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Birds are listed for countries included within their breeding or wintering ranges.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fish species, threatened
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fish species are based on Froese, R. and Pauly, D. (eds). 2008. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Froese, R. and Pauly, D. (eds). 2008. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org. version (07/2008). Accessed: 28 September 2008.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Plant species (higher), threatened
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Higher plants are native vascular plant species. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Plant species (higher), total known
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Higher plants are native vascular plant species. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mammal species, threatened
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mammal species are mammals excluding whales and porpoises. Threatened species are the number of species classified by the IUCN as endangered, vulnerable, rare, indeterminate, out of danger, or insufficiently known.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, and International Union for Conservation of Nature, Red List of Threatened Species.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Non-agricultural population (FAO, numbers)
Population density (people per sq. km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population density is midyear population divided by land area in square kilometers. Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of their country of origin. Land area is a country's total area, excluding area under inland water bodies, national claims to continental shelf, and exclusive economic zones. In most cases the definition of inland water bodies includes major rivers and lakes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization and World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population living in slums, (% of urban population)
Rural population density (rural population per sq. km of arable land)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rural population density is the rural population divided by the arable land area. Rural population is calculated as the difference between the total population and the urban population. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. Land abandoned as a result of shifting cultivation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization and World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population in largest city
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population in largest city is the urban population living in the country's largest metropolitan area.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population in the largest city (% of urban population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population in largest city is the percentage of a country's urban population living in that country's largest metropolitan area.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population in urban agglomerations of more than 1 million
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population in urban agglomerations of more than one million is the country's population living in metropolitan areas that in 2000 had a population of more than one million people.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population in urban agglomerations of more than 1 million (% of total population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population in urban agglomerations of more than one million is the percentage of a country's population living in metropolitan areas that in 2000 had a population of more than one million people.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pump price for diesel fuel (US$ per liter)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fuel prices refer to the pump prices of the most widely sold grade of diesel fuel. Prices have been converted from the local currency to U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: German Agency for Technical Cooperation (GTZ).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pump price for gasoline (US$ per liter)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fuel prices refer to the pump prices of the most widely sold grade of gasoline. Prices have been converted from the local currency to U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: German Agency for Technical Cooperation (GTZ).

wb:indicator.wb:name: GEF benefits index for biodiversity (0 = no biodiversity potential to 100 = maximum)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GEF benefits index for biodiversity is a composite index of relative biodiversity potential for each country based on the species represented in each country, their threat status, and the diversity of habitat types in each country. The index has been normalized so that values run from 0 (no biodiversity potential) to 100 (maximum biodiversity potential).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Kiran Dev Pandey, Piet Buys, Ken Chomitz, and David Wheeler's, "Biodiversity Conservation Indicators: New Tools for Priority Setting at the Global Environment Facility" (2006).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agriculture productivity (constant 2000 US$ agriculture value added per cubic meter of agriculture freshwater withdrawal)
Industry productivity (constant 2000 US$ industry value added per cubic meter of industry freshwater withdrawal)
Water productivity, total (constant 2000 US$ GDP per cubic meter of total freshwater withdrawal)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Water productivity is calculated as GDP in constant prices divided by annual total water withdrawal.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annual freshwater withdrawals, agriculture (% of total freshwater withdrawal)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annual freshwater withdrawals, domestic (% of total freshwater withdrawal)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annual freshwater withdrawals, industry (% of total freshwater withdrawal)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for industry are total withdrawals for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annual freshwater withdrawals, total (billion cubic meters)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture and industry are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production and for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Annual freshwater withdrawals, total (% of internal resources)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual freshwater withdrawals refer to total water withdrawals, not counting evaporation losses from storage basins. Withdrawals also include water from desalination plants in countries where they are a significant source. Withdrawals can exceed 100 percent of total renewable resources where extraction from nonrenewable aquifers or desalination plants is considerable or where there is significant water reuse. Withdrawals for agriculture and industry are total withdrawals for irrigation and livestock production and for direct industrial use (including withdrawals for cooling thermoelectric plants). Withdrawals for domestic uses include drinking water, municipal use or supply, and use for public services, commercial establishments, and homes. Data are for the most recent year available for 1987-2002.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Renewable internal freshwater resources, total (billion cubic meters)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Renewable internal freshwater resources flows refer to internal renewable resources (internal river flows and groundwater from rainfall) in the country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Renewable internal freshwater resources per capita (cubic meters)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Renewable internal freshwater resources flows refer to internal renewable resources (internal river flows and groundwater from rainfall) in the country. Renewable internal freshwater resources per capita are calculated using the World Bank's population estimates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, AQUASTAT data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nationally protected areas (sq. km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nationally protected areas are totally or partially protected areas of at least 1,000 hectares that are designated as scientific reserves with limited public access, national parks, natural monuments, nature reserves or wildlife sanctuaries, protected landscapes, and areas managed mainly for sustainable use. Marine areas, unclassified areas, and litoral (intertidal) areas are not included. The data also do not include sites protected under local or provincial law.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Terrestrial protected areas (number)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Terrestrial protected areas are those officially documented by national authorities.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Terrestrial protected areas (% of total surface area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Terrestrial protected areas are those officially documented by national authorities.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nationally protected areas (% of total area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nationally protected areas are totally or partially protected areas of at least 1,000 hectares that are designated as scientific reserves with limited public access, national parks, natural monuments, nature reserves or wildlife sanctuaries, protected landscapes, and areas managed mainly for sustainable use. Marine areas, unclassified areas, and litoral (intertidal) areas are not included. The data also do not include sites protected under local or provincial law.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Marine protected areas (sq. km)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Marine protected areas are areas of intertidal or subtidal terrain--and overlying water and associated flora and fauna and historical and cultural features--that have been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Marine protected areas (number)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Marine protected areas are areas of intertidal or subtidal terrain--and overlying water and associated flora and fauna and historical and cultural features--that have been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Marine protected areas (% of total surface area)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Marine protected areas are areas of intertidal or subtidal terrain--and overlying water and associated flora and fauna and historical and cultural features--that have been reserved by law or other effective means to protect part or all of the enclosed environment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Environmental Program and the World Conservation Monitoring Centre, as compiled by the World Resources Institute, based on data from national authorities, national legislation and international agreements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export concentration index
Export destination index
Export diversification index
Bank nonperfoming loans to total gross loans (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Bank nonperforming loans to total gross loans are the value of nonperforming loans divided by the total value of the loan portfolio (including nonperforming loans before the deduction of specific loan-loss provisions). The loan amount recorded as nonperforming should be the gross value of the loan as recorded on the balance sheet, not just the amount that is overdue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Global Financial Stability Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Bank capital to assets ratio (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Bank capital to assets is the ratio of bank capital and reserves to total assets. Capital and reserves include funds contributed by owners, retained earnings, general and special reserves, provisions, and valuation adjustments. Capital includes tier 1 capital (paid-up shares and common stock), which is a common feature in all countries' banking systems, and total regulatory capital, which includes several specified types of subordinated debt instruments that need not be repaid if the funds are required to maintain minimum capital levels (these comprise tier 2 and tier 3 capital). Total assets include all nonfinancial and financial assets.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Global Financial Stability Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Bank liquid reserves to bank assets ratio (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of bank liquid reserves to bank assets is the ratio of domestic currency holdings and deposits with the monetary authorities to claims on other governments, nonfinancial public enterprises, the private sector, and other banking institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gold, valued at year-end London prices (current US$)
Total reserves (includes gold, current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total reserves including gold valued at London gold price (current US$)
Total reserves includes gold (% of GDP)
Total reserves (% of total external debt)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International reserves to total external debt stocks.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Development Finance.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total reserves in months of imports
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices. This item shows reserves expressed in terms of the number of months of imports of goods and services they could pay for [Reserves/(Imports/12)].
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total reserves in months of imports of goods and services
Total reserves minus gold (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total reserves minus gold comprise special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. Gold holdings are excluded. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to government, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on central government, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total assets, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net foreign assets, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on other official entities, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on nonmonetary financial institutions, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector and other financial institutions, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to private sector, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit is the sum of net credit to the nonfinancial public sector, credit to the private sector, and other accounts. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on governments and other public entities (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises, advances against future credit authorizations, and purchases of treasury bills and bonds, net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on governments and other public entities (% of GDP)
Claims on governments, etc. (annual growth as % of M2)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises, advances against future credit authorizations, and purchases of treasury bills and bonds, net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Money and quasi money (M2) comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on central government (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total assets (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net foreign assets (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net foreign assets (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net foreign assets are the sum of foreign assets held by monetary authorities and deposit money banks, less their foreign liabilities. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to other official entities, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to other private financial institutions, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector (annual growth as % of M2)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on private sector (IFS line 32d) include gross credit from the financial system to individuals, enterprises, nonfinancial public entities not included under net domestic credit, and financial institutions not included elsewhere. Money and quasi money (M2) comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to rest of economy, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2), flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other liabilities excluding M2, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money is the sum of currency outside banks and demand deposits other than those of central government. This series, frequently referred to as M1 is a narrower definition of money than M2. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2) (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition of money supply is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2) as % of GDP
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition of money supply is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2) to total reserves ratio
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Average annual growth rate in money and quasi money. Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). The change in the money supply is measured as the difference in end-of-year totals relative to the level of M2 in the preceding year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Quasi money (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Quasi money refers to time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other liabilities excluding M2 (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central bank intervention rate (%)
Consumer price index (2005 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumer price index reflects changes in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Inflation, consumer prices (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inflation as measured by the consumer price index reflects the annual percentage change in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: General wages index (1987 = 100)
Other wages (urban, manufacturing, etc.) index (1987 = 100)
Wholesale price index (2005 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wholesale price index refers to a mix of agricultural and industrial goods at various stages of production and distribution, including import duties. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Deposit interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Deposit interest rate is the rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand, time, or savings deposits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real deposit interest rate (%)
Bond interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International interest rate, implicit (%)
Lending interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Lending interest rate is the rate charged by banks on loans to prime customers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest rate spread (lending rate minus deposit rate, %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest rate spread is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to prime customers minus the interest rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand, time, or savings deposits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money market rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Real interest rate is the lending interest rate adjusted for inflation as measured by the GDP deflator.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files using World Bank data on the GDP deflator.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Risk premium on lending (prime rate minus treasury bill rate, %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Risk premium on lending is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to prime private sector customers minus the "risk free" treasury bill interest rate at which short-term government securities are issued or traded in the market. In some countries this spread may be negative, indicating that the market considers its best corporate clients to be lower risk than the government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time deposits interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real interest on time deposit (%)
Domestic credit provided by banking sector (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic credit provided by the banking sector includes all credit to various sectors on a gross basis, with the exception of credit to the central government, which is net. The banking sector includes monetary authorities and deposit money banks, as well as other banking institutions where data are available (including institutions that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other banking institutions are savings and mortgage loan institutions and building and loan associations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Domestic credit to private sector (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector, such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Liquid liabilities (M3) as % of GDP
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Liquid liabilities are also known as broad money, or M3. They are the sum of currency and deposits in the central bank (M0), plus transferable deposits and electronic currency (M1), plus time and savings deposits, foreign currency transferable deposits, certificates of deposit, and securities repurchase agreements (M2), plus travelers checks, foreign currency time deposits, commercial paper, and shares of mutual funds or market funds held by residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Quasi-liquid liabilities (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Quasi-liquid liabilities are the sum of currency and deposits in the central bank (M0), plus time and savings deposits, foreign currency transferable deposits, certificates of deposit, and securities repurchase agreements, plus travelers checks, foreign currency time deposits, commercial paper, and shares of mutual funds or market funds held by residents. They equal the M3 money supply less transferable deposits and electronic currency (M1).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Demand deposits (current LCU)
Time deposits (current LCU)
Adjustments to foreign scheduled principal repayments (current LCU)
Current budget balance, including grants (current LCU)
Overall budget balance, including grants (current LCU)
Overall surplus/deficit, excluding current grants (current LCU)
Overall surplus/deficit, excluding all grants (current LCU)
Primary balance, excluding interest (current LCU)
Central government debt, monetary system credit (current LCU)
Central government debt, other domestic (current LCU)
External debt, end year (current US$)
External debt, end year (current LCU)
Total government debt (current LCU)
Central government arrears on domestic debt (current LCU)
Central government arrears on external debt (current LCU)
External borrowing, net (current LCU)
Domestic financing, monetary system credit (current LCU)
Other domestic borrowing (current LCU)
Financing, including external capital grants (current LCU)
Total current grants (current LCU)
External capital grants (current LCU)
Nontax receipts (current LCU)
Total revenue including current grants (current LCU)
Central government revenue excluding all grants (current LCU)
Central government revenues, excluding all grants (% of GDP)
Total currrent revenues including current grants (current LCU)
Current revenue, excluding grants (current LCU)
Capital revenue (current LCU)
Highest marginal tax rate, corporate rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Highest marginal tax rate (corporate rate) is the highest rate shown on the schedule of tax rates applied to the taxable income of corporations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: KPMG's Corporate and Indirect Tax Rate Survey 2009 (www.kpmg.com), and PricewaterhouseCoopers's Worldwide Tax Summaries Online (www.pwc.com).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Direct taxes (current LCU)
Taxes on goods and services, GB (current LCU)
Indirect taxes (current LCU)
Highest marginal tax rate, individual (on income exceeding, US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Highest marginal tax rate (individual rate) is the highest rate shown on the schedule of tax rates applied to the taxable income of individuals. This series presents the income levels for individuals above which the highest marginal tax rates levied at the national level apply.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: KPMG's Individual Income Tax and Social Security Rate Survey 2009 (www.kpmg.com), and PricewaterhouseCoopers's Worldwide Tax Summaries Online (www.pwc.com).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Highest marginal tax rate, individual rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Highest marginal tax rate (individual rate) is the highest rate shown on the schedule of tax rates applied to the taxable income of individuals.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: KPMG's Individual Income Tax and Social Security Rate Survey 2009 (www.kpmg.com), and PricewaterhouseCoopers's Worldwide Tax Summaries Online (www.pwc.com).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on international trade, GB (current LCU)
Adjustments to foreign scheduled debt service (current LCU)
Central government debt service, external (current LCU)
Government consumption (current LCU)
Interest on domestic debt (current LCU)
Interest on external debt (current LCU)
Subsidies (GFS, current LCU)
Current expenditure, total (current LCU)
Other current transfers (current LCU)
Wages and salaries (current LCU)
Defense expenditure (current LCU)
Total expenditure and net lending (current LCU)
Research and development expenditure (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expenditures for research and development are current and capital expenditures (both public and private) on creative work undertaken systematically to increase knowledge, including knowledge of humanity, culture, and society, and the use of knowledge for new applications. R&D covers basic research, applied research, and experimental development.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total capital expenditure and net lending (current LCU)
Budgetary investment (current LCU)
Capital transfers (current LCU)
Fiscal balance, cash surplus/deficit (current US$)
Cash surplus/deficit (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cash surplus or deficit is revenue (including grants) minus expense, minus net acquisition of nonfinancial assets. In the 1986 GFS manual nonfinancial assets were included under revenue and expenditure in gross terms. This cash surplus or deficit is closest to the earlier overall budget balance (still missing is lending minus repayments, which are now a financing item under net acquisition of financial assets).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cash surplus/deficit (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cash surplus or deficit is revenue (including grants) minus expense, minus net acquisition of nonfinancial assets. In the 1986 GFS manual nonfinancial assets were included under revenue and expenditure in gross terms. This cash surplus or deficit is closest to the earlier overall budget balance (still missing is lending minus repayments, which are now a financing item under net acquisition of financial assets).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt, total (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt, total (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, domestic (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, domestic (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, foreign (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, foreign (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Grants and other revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Grants and other revenue include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; interest; dividends; rent; requited, nonrepayable receipts for public purposes (such as fines, administrative fees, and entrepreneurial income from government owner­ship of property); and voluntary, unrequited, nonrepayable receipts other than grants.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Grants and other revenue (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Grants and other revenue include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; interest; dividends; rent; requited, nonrepayable receipts for public purposes (such as fines, administrative fees, and entrepreneurial income from government owner­ship of property); and voluntary, unrequited, nonrepayable receipts other than grants.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Social contributions (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Social contributions include social security contributions by employees, employers, and self-employed individuals, and other contributions whose source cannot be determined. They also include actual or imputed contributions to social insurance schemes operated by governments.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Social contributions (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Social contributions include social security contributions by employees, employers, and self-employed individuals, and other contributions whose source cannot be determined. They also include actual or imputed contributions to social insurance schemes operated by governments.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total revenue (current US$)
Total revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue, excluding grants (current US$)
Revenue, excluding grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue, excluding grants (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on exports (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on exports are all levies on goods being transported out of the country or services being delivered to nonresidents by residents. Rebates on exported goods that are repayments of previously paid general consumption taxes, excise taxes, or import duties are deducted from the gross amounts receivable from these taxes, not from amounts receivable from export taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on exports (% of tax revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on exports are all levies on goods being transported out of the country or services being delivered to nonresidents by residents. Rebates on exported goods that are repayments of previously paid general consumption taxes, excise taxes, or import duties are deducted from the gross amounts receivable from these taxes, not from amounts receivable from export taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services (% value added of industry and services)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD value added estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Customs and other import duties (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Customs and other import duties are all levies collected on goods that are entering the country or services delivered by nonresidents to residents. They include levies imposed for revenue or protection purposes and determined on a specific or ad valorem basis as long as they are restricted to imported goods or services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Customs and other import duties (% of tax revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Customs and other import duties are all levies collected on goods that are entering the country or services delivered by nonresidents to residents. They include levies imposed for revenue or protection purposes and determined on a specific or ad valorem basis as long as they are restricted to imported goods or services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on international trade (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on international trade (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other taxes (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other taxes include employer payroll or labor taxes, taxes on property, and taxes not allocable to other categories, such as penalties for late payment or nonpayment of taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other taxes (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other taxes include employer payroll or labor taxes, taxes on property, and taxes not allocable to other categories, such as penalties for late payment or nonpayment of taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tax revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tax revenue refers to compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Certain compulsory transfers such as fines, penalties, and most social security contributions are excluded. Refunds and corrections of erroneously collected tax revenue are treated as negative revenue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tax revenue (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tax revenue refers to compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Certain compulsory transfers such as fines, penalties, and most social security contributions are excluded. Refunds and corrections of erroneously collected tax revenue are treated as negative revenue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on income, profits and capital gains (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on income, profits and capital gains (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on income, profits and capital gains (% of total taxes)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Compensation of employees (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compensation of employees consists of all payments in cash, as well as in kind (such as food and housing), to employees in return for services rendered, and government contributions to social insurance schemes such as social security and pensions that provide benefits to employees.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Compensation of employees (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compensation of employees consists of all payments in cash, as well as in kind (such as food and housing), to employees in return for services rendered, and government contributions to social insurance schemes such as social security and pensions that provide benefits to employees.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Goods and services expense (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Goods and services include all government payments in exchange for goods and services used for the production of market and nonmarket goods and services. Own-account capital formation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Goods and services expense (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Goods and services include all government payments in exchange for goods and services used for the production of market and nonmarket goods and services. Own-account capital formation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest payments (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest payments (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest payments (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other expense (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other expense is spending on dividends, rent, and other miscellaneous expenses, including provision for consumption of fixed capital.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other expense (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other expense is spending on dividends, rent, and other miscellaneous expenses, including provision for consumption of fixed capital.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expense (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expense (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expense (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies and other transfers (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies, grants, and other social benefits include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises; grants to foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; and social security, social assistance benefits, and employer social benefits in cash and in kind.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies and other transfers (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies, grants, and other social benefits include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises; grants to foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; and social security, social assistance benefits, and employer social benefits in cash and in kind.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: primary completion rate, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary completion rate, female is the number of non-repeating female students in the last grade of primary school divided by the female population of the official age of the last grade of primary. The trend projections are based on the average historical change in the period 2000-2009. If intake rates were rising, they are assumed to increase at the same historical rate; if they were declining, then they are assumed to remain constant. If repetition and dropout rates were falling, they are assumed to decrease at the same historical rate; if they were rising, then they are assumed to remain constant.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Education Policy Data Center (EPDC)

wb:indicator.wb:name: primary completion rate, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary completion rate, male is the number of non-repeating male students in the last grade of primary school divided by the male population of the official age of the last grade of primary. The trend projections are based on the average historical change in the period 2000-2009. If intake rates were rising, they are assumed to increase at the same historical rate; if they were declining, then they are assumed to remain constant. If repetition and dropout rates were falling, they are assumed to decrease at the same historical rate; if they were rising, then they are assumed to remain constant.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Education Policy Data Center (EPDC)

wb:indicator.wb:name: primary completion rate, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary completion rate, total is the number of non-repeating students in the last grade of primary school divided by the population of the official age of the last grade of primary. The trend projections are based on the average historical change in the period 2000-2009. If intake rates were rising, they are assumed to increase at the same historical rate; if they were declining, then they are assumed to remain constant. If repetition and dropout rates were falling, they are assumed to decrease at the same historical rate; if they were rising, then they are assumed to remain constant.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Education Policy Data Center (EPDC)

Protecting investors, director liability index
Business extent of disclosure index (0=less disclosure to 10=more disclosure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Disclosure index measures the extent to which investors are protected through disclosure of ownership and financial information. The index ranges from 0 to 10, with higher values indicating more disclosure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Doing Business project (http://www.doingbusiness.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ease of doing business index (1=most business-friendly regulations)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ease of doing business index ranks economies from 1 to 183, with first place being the best. A high ranking means that the regulatory environment is conducive to business operation. The index ranks the simple average of the country's percentile rankings on 10 topics covered in the World Bank's Doing Business. The ranking on each topic is the simple average of the percentile rankings on its component indicators.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Doing Business project (http://www.doingbusiness.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Protecting investors, investor protection index
New businesses registered (number)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: New businesses registered are the number of new firms, defined as firms registered in the current year of reporting.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Finance Corporation's micro, small, and medium-size enterprises database (http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/sme.nsf/Content/Resources).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Business entry rate (new registrations as % of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Business entry rate shows the number of new firms, defined as firms registered in the current year of reporting, expressed as a percentage of total registered firms. Data are collected on firm entry and exit and total firms. Because of underreporting of firms that have closed or exited, especially in developing countries, the data on total registered firms may be biased upward.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Finance Corporation's micro, small, and medium-size enterprises database (http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/sme.nsf/Content/Resources).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Protecting investors, shareholder suits index
Total businesses registered (number)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total businesses registered. Because of underreporting of firms that have closed or exited, especially in developing countries, the data on total registered firms may be biased upward.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Finance Corporation's micro, small, and medium-size enterprises database (http://www.ifc.org/ifcext/sme.nsf/Content/Resources).
