wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inpatient admission rate is the percentage of the population admitted to hospitals during a year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, OECD and supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Condom use with non regular partner, % adults(15-49), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Condom use at last high-risk sex is the percentage of the population ages 15-49 who used a condom at last intercourse with a non-marital and non-cohabiting sexual partner in the last 12 months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys from national sources.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Condom use with non regular partner, % adults(15-49), male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Condom use at last high-risk sex is the percentage of the population ages 15-49 who used a condom at last intercourse with a non-marital and non-cohabiting sexual partner in the last 12 months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys from national sources.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Hospital, average length of stay (days)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Average length of stay is the average duration of inpatient hospital admissions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, OECD and supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cause of death, by communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths by underlying causes. Communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions include infectious and parasitic diseases, respiratory infections, and nutritional deficiencies such as underweight and stunting.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived based on the data from WHO's World Health Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cause of death, by injury (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths by underlying causes. Non-communicable diseases include cancer, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, digestive diseases, skin diseases, musculoskeletal diseases, and congenital anomalies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived based on the data from WHO's World Health Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cause of death, by non-communicable diseases (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths by underlying causes. Injuries include unintentional and intentional injuries.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived based on the data from WHO's World Health Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adults (ages 15+) living with HIV
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults living with HIV refers to the number of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: AIDS estimated deaths (UNAIDS estimates)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: AIDS deaths are the estimated number of adults and children who died due to AIDS-related causes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female adults with HIV (% of population ages 15+ with HIV)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Female rate is as a percentage of the total population with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV prevalence rate, adult 15-49 years (%; high estimate)
HIV prevalence rate, adult 15-49 years (%; low estimate)
Prevalence of HIV, total (% of population ages 15-49)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, female child (per 1,000 female children age one)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International, Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF, Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control, and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health. See footnotes for a source.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, male child (per 1,000 male children age one)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International, Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF, Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control, and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health. See footnotes for a source.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Level & Trends in Child Mortality. Report 2010. Estimates Developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA, UNPD).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Met need for contraception (% of married women ages 15-49)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Met need for contraception shows the percentage of married women ages 15-49 whose need for family planning is satisfied.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved water source, rural (% of rural population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population with reasonable access to an adequate amount of water from an improved source, such as a household connection, public standpipe, borehole, protected well or spring, and rainwater collection. Unimproved sources include vendors, tanker trucks, and unprotected wells and springs. Reasonable access is defined as the availability of at least 20 liters a person a day from a source within one kilometer of the dwelling.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved water source, urban (% of urban population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population with reasonable access to an adequate amount of water from an improved source, such as a household connection, public standpipe, borehole, protected well or spring, and rainwater collection. Unimproved sources include vendors, tanker trucks, and unprotected wells and springs. Reasonable access is defined as the availability of at least 20 liters a person a day from a source within one kilometer of the dwelling.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved water source (% of population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population with reasonable access to an adequate amount of water from an improved source, such as a household connection, public standpipe, borehole, protected well or spring, and rainwater collection. Unimproved sources include vendors, tanker trucks, and unprotected wells and springs. Reasonable access is defined as the availability of at least 20 liters a person a day from a source within one kilometer of the dwelling.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: People living with HIV/AIDS, children 0-14 years (high estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, children 0-14 years (low estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, children 0-14 years
People living with HIV/AIDS, adults 15+ years (high estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, adults 15+ years (low estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, adults 15+ years
People living with HIV/AIDS, women 15+ years (high estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, women 15+ years (low estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, women 15+ years
People living with HIV/AIDS, total (high estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, total (low estimate)
People living with HIV/AIDS, total
HIV prevalence rate, young women 15-24 years (%; high estimate)
HIV prevalence rate, young women 15-24 years (%; low estimate)
Prevalence of HIV, female (% ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Comprehensive correct knowledge of HIV/AIDS, ages 15-24, female (2 prevent ways and reject 3 misconceptions)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The percent of female respondents ages 15-24 who correctly identify the two major ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV (using condoms and limiting sex to one faithful, uninfected partner), who reject the two most common local misconceptions about HIV transmission, and who know that a healthy-looking person can have HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Comprehensive correct knowledge of HIV/AIDS, ages 15-24, male (2 prevent ways and reject 3 misconceptions)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The percent of male respondents ages 15-24 who correctly identify the two major ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV (using condoms and limiting sex to one faithful, uninfected partner), who reject the two most common local misconceptions about HIV transmission, and who know that a healthy-looking person can have HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV prevalence rate, young men 15-24 years (%; high estimate)
HIV prevalence rate, young men 15-24 years (%; low estimate)
Prevalence of HIV, male (% ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV prevalence among 15-to-24-year-old pregnant women in capital city (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: HIV prevalence among 15-to-24-year-old pregnant women in capital city are the percentage of pregnant women ages 15-24 in the capital city who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Antiretroviral therapy coverage (% of people with advanced HIV infection)
AIDS deaths in adults and children (high estimate)
AIDS deaths in adults and children (low estimate)
AIDS deaths in adults and children
% of females ages 15-49 having comprehensive correct knowledge about HIV (2 prevent ways and reject 3 misconceptions)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Knowledge of HIV is the percentage of respondents who correctly identify the two major ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV (using condoms and limiting sex to one faithful, uninfected partner), who reject the two most common local misconceptions about HIV transmission, and who know that a healthy-looking person can have HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys.

wb:indicator.wb:name: % of males ages 15-49 having comprehensive correct knowledge about HIV (2 prevent ways and reject 3 misconceptions)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Knowledge of HIV is the percentage of respondents who correctly identify the two major ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV (using condoms and limiting sex to one faithful, uninfected partner), who reject the two most common local misconceptions about HIV transmission, and who know that a healthy-looking person can have HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Orphans 0-17 years currently living (high estimate)
Orphans 0-17 years currently living (low estimate)
Orphans 0-17 years currently living
Children orphaned by HIV/AIDS
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of children orphaned by HIV/AIDS is the estimated number of children who have lost their mother or both parents to AIDS before age 15 since the epidemic began. Some of the orphaned children included in this cumulative total are no longer alive; others are no longer under age 15.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%; high estimate)
HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%; high estimate)
Number of HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals
HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%)
Adults (ages 15+) and children (0-14 years) living with HIV
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults living with HIV refers to the number of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, HepB3 (% of one-year-old children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization rate, hepatitis B is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, BCG (% of one-year-old children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization rate, BCG is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey for BCG. A child is considered adequately immunized after one dose.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, DPT (% of children ages 12-23 months)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against diphtheria, pertussis (or whooping cough), and tetanus (DPT) after receiving three doses of vaccine.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, measles (% of children ages 12-23 months)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against measles after receiving one dose of vaccine.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, Pol3 (% of one-year-old children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization rate, Polio is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Hospital beds (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Hospital beds include inpatient beds available in public, private, general, and specialized hospitals and rehabilitation centers. In most cases beds for both acute and chronic care are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Community health workers (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Community health workers include various types of community health aides, many with country-specific occupational titles such as community health officers, community health-education workers, family health workers, lady health visitors and health extension package workers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Midwives (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Midwives are professional midwives, auxiliary midwives, and enrolled midwives.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nurses and midwives (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nurses and midwives include professional nurses, professional midwives, auxiliary nurses, auxiliary midwives, enrolled nurses, enrolled midwives and other associated personnel, such as dental nurses and primary care nurses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nurses (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nurses are professional nurses, auxiliary nurses, enrolled nurses, and other nurses, such as dental nurses and primary care nurses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Physicians (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Physicians include generalist and specialist medical practitioners.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets (% of under-5 population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets refers to the percentage of children under age five who slept under an insecticide-treated bednet to prevent malaria.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Use of preventive treatment for malaria (% of pregnant women)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Use of preventive treatment for malaria shows the prophylactic use of antimalarial drugs and use of Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) by women during pregnancy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs (% of children under age 5 with fever)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malaria treatment refers to the percentage of children under age five who were ill with fever in the last two weeks and received any appropriate (locally defined) anti-malarial drugs.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of weeks of maternity leave
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of weeks of maternity leave are the number of weeks that maternity leave benefits are provided.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World's Women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in: rate varies by country)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "Maternal Mortality: Estimates Developed by WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA and the World Bank"

wb:indicator.wb:name: Maternal leave benefits (% of wages paid in covered period)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Maternity leave benefits are the percentage of wages paid during the maternity leave.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World's Women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking prevalence, total, ages 15+
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of smoking is the percentage of men and women ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, and pipes, and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking prevalence, females (% of adults)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of smoking, female is the percentage of women ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, and pipes, and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking prevalence, males (% of adults)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of smoking, male is the percentage of men ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, and pipes, and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population using solid fuels, total (% of population)
Improved sanitation facilities (% of population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population with at least adequate access to excreta disposal facilities that can effectively prevent human, animal, and insect contact with excreta. Improved facilities range from simple but protected pit latrines to flush toilets with a sewerage connection. To be effective, facilities must be correctly constructed and properly maintained.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved sanitation facilities, rural (% of rural population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population with at least adequate access to excreta disposal facilities that can effectively prevent human, animal, and insect contact with excreta. Improved facilities range from simple but protected pit latrines to flush toilets with a sewerage connection. To be effective, facilities must be correctly constructed and properly maintained.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved sanitation facilities, urban (% of urban population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population with at least adequate access to excreta disposal facilities that can effectively prevent human, animal, and insect contact with excreta. Improved facilities range from simple but protected pit latrines to flush toilets with a sewerage connection. To be effective, facilities must be correctly constructed and properly maintained.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization and United Nations Children's Fund, Joint Measurement Programme (JMP) (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care of at least four visits (% of pregnant women)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care, at least four times, are the percentage of women attended at least four times during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care are the percentage of women attended at least once during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: ARI treatment (% of children under 5 taken to a health provider)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children with acute respiratory infection (ARI) who are taken to a health provider refers to the percentage of children under age five with ARI in the last two weeks who were taken to an appropriate health provider, including hospital, health center, dispensary, village health worker, clinic, and private physician.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exclusive breastfeeding (% of children under 6 months)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exclusive breastfeeding refers to the percentage of children less than six months old who are fed breast milk alone (no other liquids) in the past 24 hours.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Births attended by skilled health staff (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Births attended by skilled health staff are the percentage of deliveries attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision, care, and advice to women during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period; to conduct deliveries on their own; and to care for newborns.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Low-birthweight babies (% of births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Low-birthweight babies are newborns weighing less than 2,500 grams, with the measurement taken within the first hours of life, before significant postnatal weight loss has occurred.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Diabetes prevalence (% of population ages 20 to 79)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Diabetes prevalence is the percentage of people ages 20-79 who have type 1 or type 2 diabetes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Diabetes Federation.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, weight for age (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malaria cases reported
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Reported cases of malaria are the number reported with malaria infection.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Health Atlas. (http://apps.who.int/globalatlas/dataQuery/default.asp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate, per 100,000 live births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die during pregnancy and childbirth, per 100,000 live births. The data are estimated with a regression model using information on fertility, birth attendants, and HIV prevalence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990-2008. Estimates Developed by WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Diarrhea treatment (% of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children with diarrhea who received oral rehydration and continued feeding refer to the percentage of children under age five with diarrhea in the two weeks prior to the survey who received either oral rehydration therapy or increased fluids, with continued feeding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of overweight, female (% of female population ages 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of overweight adult is the percentage of adults ages 15 and over whose Body Mass Index (BMI) is more than 25 kg/m². Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple index of weight-for-height, or the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of overweight, male (% of male population ages 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of overweight adult is the percentage of adults ages 15 and over whose Body Mass Index (BMI) is more than 25 kg/m². Body Mass Index (BMI) is a simple index of weight-for-height, or the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of overweight (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, height for age (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age (stunting) is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of wasting (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis treatment success rate (% of registered cases)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis treatment success rate is the percentage of new, registered smear-positive (infectious) cases that were cured or in which a full course of treatment was completed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis cases detected under DOTS (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: DOTS detection rate is the percentage of estimated new infectious tuberculosis cases detected under the directly observed treatment, short course case detection and treatment strategy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis case detection rate (all forms)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis case detection rate (all forms) is the percentage of newly notified tuberculosis cases (including relapses) to estimated incident cases (case detection, all forms).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary, smear positive, and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis death rate (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis death rate is the number of deaths from tuberculosis per 100,000 population. Incidence, prevalence and mortality estimates include patients with HIV. Estimates for all years are re-calculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis prevalence rate (per 100,000 population, WHO)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis prevalence rate is the number of illnesses, accidents or sick persons per 100,000 population, without distinction between new and old cases. Incidence, prevalence and mortality estimates include patients with HIV. Estimates for all years are re-calculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Outpatient visits per capita
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Outpatient visits per capita are the number of visits to health care facilities per capita, including repeat visits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, OECD and supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External resources for health (% of total expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: External resources for health are funds or services in kind that are provided by entities not part of the country in question. The resources may come from international organizations, other countries through bilateral arrangements, or foreign nongovernmental organizations. These resources are part of total health expenditure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of private expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Out of pocket expenditure is any direct outlay by households, including gratuities and in-kind payments, to health practitioners and suppliers of pharmaceuticals, therapeutic appliances, and other goods and services whose primary intent is to contribute to the restoration or enhancement of the health status of individuals or population groups. It is a part of private health expenditure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure per capita (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government health expenditure per capita (current US$)
Health expenditure per capita, PPP (constant 2005 international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in international dollars converted using 2005 purchasing power parity (PPP) rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, private (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private health expenditure includes direct household (out-of-pocket) spending, private insurance, charitable donations, and direct service payments by private corporations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private prepaid plans (% of private expenditure on health)
Health expenditure, private (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private health expenditure includes direct household (out-of-pocket) spending, private insurance, charitable donations, and direct service payments by private corporations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, public (% of total health expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds. Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, public (% of government expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, public (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Social Security expenditure on health (% government expenditure on health)
Health expenditure (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, total (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (www.who.int/nha/en) supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by second 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by third 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by fourth 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by highest 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by highest 10%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by lowest 10%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by lowest 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty headcount ratio at $2 a day (PPP) (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population below $2 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $2.00 a day at 2005 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty headcount ratio at $1.25 a day (PPP) (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population below $1.25 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $1.25 a day at 2005 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at $2 a day (PPP) (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Poverty gap is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at $1.25 a day (PPP) (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Poverty gap is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: GINI index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income (or, in some cases, consumption expenditure) among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/jsp/index.jsp).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at national poverty line (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Poverty gap at national poverty line is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall) as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty headcount ratio at national poverty line (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: National poverty rate is the percentage of the population living below the national poverty line. National estimates are based on population-weighted subgroup estimates from household surveys.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at rural poverty line (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Poverty gap at rural poverty line is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall) as a percentage of the national rural poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty headcount ratio at rural poverty line (% of rural population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rural poverty rate is the percentage of the rural population living below the national rural poverty line.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at urban poverty line (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Poverty gap at urban poverty line is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall) as a percentage of the national urban poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty headcount ratio at urban poverty line (% of urban population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Urban poverty rate is the percentage of the urban population living below the national urban poverty line.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in agriculture, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes agriculture and hunting, forestry and logging, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in agriculture, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes agriculture and hunting, forestry and logging, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in agriculture (% of economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes agriculture and hunting, forestry and logging, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, agriculture, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, agriculture, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment in agriculture (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, female (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, male (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, total (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Share of women employed in the nonagricultural sector (% of total nonagricultural employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of women employed in the nonagricultural sector is the share of female workers in the nonagricultural sector (industry and services), expressed as a percentage of total employment in the nonagricultural sector. Industry includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, electricity, gas, and water, corresponding to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3). Services include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services-corresponding to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, 15+, female (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, 15+, male (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, 15+, total (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vulnerable employment, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vulnerable employment is unpaid family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vulnerable employment, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vulnerable employment is unpaid family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vulnerable employment, total (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vulnerable employment is unpaid family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per person employed (constant 1990 PPP $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per person employed is gross domestic product (GDP) divided by total employment in the economy. Purchasing power parity (PPP) GDP is GDP converted to 1990 constant international dollars using PPP rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP that a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per person employed (annual % growth)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per person employed is gross domestic product (GDP) divided by total employment in the economy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, industry, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Industry corresponds to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3) and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, industry, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Industry corresponds to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3) and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment in industry (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Industry corresponds to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3) and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women in administrative and managerial positions (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women among legislators and managers refers to the proportion of legislators, senior officials and managers who are women. Legislators, senior officials and managers includes legislators and senior officials, corporate managers, and general managers (ISCO-88). Managerial positions in public sector and industry is the number of women administrators and managers as a percentage of all workers in this occupational group, and covers the latest year between 1985 to 1997 for which data are available.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in manufacturing, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in manufacturing, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in manufacturing (% of economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wages and salaries in manufacturing, female (average time period varies by country, current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wages and salaries in manufacturing, female shows the average wage earned by women in the manufacturing sector. The time period covered varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of female to male wages in manufacturing
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wage equality between women and men in manufacturing refers to female to male wages and salaries in manufacturing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wages and salaries in manufacturing, male (average time period varies by country, current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wages and salaries in manufacturing, male shows the average wage earned by men in the manufacturing sector. The time period covered varies by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in services, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in services, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in services (% of economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, services, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, services, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment in services (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time spent in domestic work, female (hours)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time spent in domestic work, female refers to hours and minutes that women spent on housework, child and adult care, gardening and pet care, construction and repairs, shopping and services, and household management.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources. Website: http://w3.unece.org/pxweb/DATABASE/STAT/Gender.stat.asp

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time spent in domestic work, male (hours)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time spent in domestic work, male refers to hours and minutes that men spent on housework, child and adult care, gardening and pet care, construction and repairs, shopping and services, and household management.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources. Website: http://w3.unece.org/pxweb/DATABASE/STAT/Gender.stat.asp

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time spent in gainful work, female (hours)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time spent in gainful work, female refers to hours and minutes that women spent on main and second jobs (including informal employment) and related activities, breaks and travel during working hours, and on job seeking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources. Website: http://w3.unece.org/pxweb/DATABASE/STAT/Gender.stat.asp

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time spent in gainful work, male (hours)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time spent in gainful work, male refers to hours and minutes that men spent on main and second jobs (including informal employment) and related activities, breaks and travel during working hours, and on job seeking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Economically active children, study and work (% of economically active children, ages 7-14)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Economically active children, work only (% of economically active children, ages 7-14)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force (15-24 years), female (% of total labor force)
Labor force (15-24 years), total

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labour force, female
Urban informal sector employment, female (% of total urban female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Informal sector employment covers persons who, during a given reference period, were employed in at least one informal enterprise, irrespective of their status in employment and whether it was their main or secondary job.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban informal sector employment, male (% of total urban male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Informal sector employment covers persons who, during a given reference period, were employed in at least one informal enterprise, irrespective of their status in employment and whether it was their main or secondary job.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban informal sector employment, total (% of total urban employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Informal sector employment covers persons who, during a given reference period, were employed in at least one informal enterprise, irrespective of their status in employment and whether it was their main or secondary job.

Labor force with primary education, female (% of female labor force)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with primary education (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with secondary education, female (% of female labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with secondary education, male (% of male labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with secondary education (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
