wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with tertiary education, female (% of female labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with tertiary education, male (% of male labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with tertiary education (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female labor force comprises all females who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, female (% of total labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which women are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force (15+ years), male (% of total labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Male labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which men are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, youth female (% of female labor force ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, youth male (% of male labor force ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, youth total (% of total labor force ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Long-term unemployment, female (% of female unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Long-term unemployment, male (% of male unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Long-term unemployment (% of total unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with primary education, female (% of female unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with primary education, male (% of male unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with primary education (% of total unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with secondary education, female (% of female unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with secondary education, male (% of male unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with secondary education (% of total unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with tertiary education, female (% of female unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with tertiary education, male (% of male unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment with tertiary education (% of total unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment by level of educational attainment shows the unemployed by level of educational attainment, as a percentage of the unemployed. The levels of educational attainment accord with the International Standard Classification of Education 1997 of the United Nations Educational, Cultural, and Scientific Organization (UNESCO).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, female (% of female labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, male (% of male labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, total (% of total labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Emigration rate of tertiary educated (% of total tertiary educated population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Emigration rate of tertiary educated shows the stock of emigrants ages 25 and older, residing in an OECD country other than that in which they were born, with at least one year of tertiary education as a percentage of the population age 25 and older with tertiary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Frédéric Docquier, Abdeslam Marfouk, and B. Lindsay Lowell's, "A Gendered Assessment of the Brain Drain" (2007).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net migration
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net migration is the net total of migrants during the period, that is, the total number of immigrants less the annual number of emigrants, including both citizens and noncitizens. Data are five-year estimates. To derive estimates of net migration, the United Nations Population Division takes into account the past migration history of a country or area, the migration policy of a country, and the influx of refugees in recent periods. The data to calculate these official estimates come from a variety of sources, including border statistics, administrative records, surveys, and censuses. When no official estimates can be made because of insufficient data, net migration is derived through the balance equation, which is the difference between overall population growth and the natural increase during the 1990-2000 intercensal period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects 2008.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Refugee population by country or territory of asylum
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Refugees are people who are recognized as refugees under the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees or its 1967 Protocol, the 1969 Organization of African Unity Convention Governing the Specific Aspects of Refugee Problems in Africa, people recognized as refugees in accordance with the UNHCR statute, people granted refugee-like humanitarian status, and people provided temporary protection. Asylum seekers--people who have applied for asylum or refugee status and who have not yet received a decision or who are registered as asylum seekers--are excluded. Palestinian refugees are people (and their descendants) whose residence was Palestine between June 1946 and May 1948 and who lost their homes and means of livelihood as a result of the 1948 Arab-Israeli conflict. Country of asylum is the country where an asylum claim was filed and granted.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), Statistical Yearbook and data files, complemented by statistics on Palestinian refugees under the mandate of the UNRWA as published on its website. Data from UNHCR are available online at: www.unhcr.org/statistics/populationdatabase.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Refugee population by country or territory of origin
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Refugees are people who are recognized as refugees under the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees or its 1967 Protocol, the 1969 Organization of African Unity Convention Governing the Specific Aspects of Refugee Problems in Africa, people recognized as refugees in accordance with the UNHCR statute, people granted refugee-like humanitarian status, and people provided temporary protection. Asylum seekers--people who have applied for asylum or refugee status and who have not yet received a decision or who are registered as asylum seekers--are excluded. Palestinian refugees are people (and their descendants) whose residence was Palestine between June 1946 and May 1948 and who lost their homes and means of livelihood as a result of the 1948 Arab-Israeli conflict. Country of origin generally refers to the nationality or country of citizenship of a claimant.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), Statistical Yearbook and data files, complemented by statistics on Palestinian refugees under the mandate of the UNRWA as published on its website. Data from UNHCR are available online at: www.unhcr.org/statistics/populationdatabase.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International migrant stock, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International migrant stock is the number of people born in a country other than that in which they live. It also includes refugees. The data used to estimate the international migrant stock at a particular time are obtained mainly from population censuses. The estimates are derived from the data on foreign-born population--people who have residence in one country but were born in another country. When data on the foreign-born population are not available, data on foreign population--that is, people who are citizens of a country other than the country in which they reside--are used as estimates. After the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991 people living in one of the newly independent countries who were born in another were classified as international migrants. Estimates of migrant stock in the newly independent states from 1990 on are based on the 1989 census of the Soviet Union. For countries with information on the international migrant stock for at least two points in time, interpolation or extrapolation was used to estimate the international migrant stock on July 1 of the reference years. For countries with only one observation, estimates for the reference years were derived using rates of change in the migrant stock in the years preceding or following the single observation available. A model was used to estimate migrants for countries that had no data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division, Trends in Total Migrant Stock: 2008 Revision.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International migrant stock (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International migrant stock is the number of people born in a country other than that in which they live. It also includes refugees. The data used to estimate the international migrant stock at a particular time are obtained mainly from population censuses. The estimates are derived from the data on foreign-born population--people who have residence in one country but were born in another country. When data on the foreign-born population are not available, data on foreign population--that is, people who are citizens of a country other than the country in which they reside--are used as estimates. After the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991 people living in one of the newly independent countries who were born in another were classified as international migrants. Estimates of migrant stock in the newly independent states from 1990 on are based on the 1989 census of the Soviet Union. For countries with information on the international migrant stock for at least two points in time, interpolation or extrapolation was used to estimate the international migrant stock on July 1 of the reference years. For countries with only one observation, estimates for the reference years were derived using rates of change in the migrant stock in the years preceding or following the single observation available. A model was used to estimate migrants for countries that had no data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division, Trends in Total Migrant Stock: 2008 Revision.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of people who are undernourished
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: People undernourished are those whose dietary energy consumption is continuously below a minimum requirement for maintaining a healthy life and carrying out light physical activity with an acceptable minimum weight for height.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of undernourishment (population)
Prevalence of undernourishment (% of population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population below minimum level of dietary energy consumption (also referred to as prevalence of undernourishment) shows the percentage of the population whose food intake is insufficient to meet dietary energy requirements continuously. Data showing as 2.5 signifies a prevalence of undernourishment below 2.5%.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization (http://www.fao.org/faostat/foodsecurity/index_en.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Depth of hunger (kilocalories per person per day)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Depth of hunger or the intensity of food deprivation, indicates how much food-deprived people fall short of minimum food needs in terms of dietary energy. The food deficit, in kilocalories per person per day, is measured by comparing the average amount of dietary energy that undernourished people get from the foods they eat with the minimum amount of dietary energy they need to maintain body weight and undertake light activity. The depth of hunger is low when it is less than 200 kilocalories per person per day, and high when it is higher than 300 kilocalories per person per day.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Food and Agriculture Organization, Food Security Statistics (http://www.fao.org/economic/ess/food-security-statistics/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Consumption of iodized salt (% of households)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumption of iodized salt refers to the percentage of households that use edible salt fortified with iodine.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Children's Fund, State of the World's Children.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vitamin A supplementation coverage rate (% of children ages 6-59 months)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vitamin A supplementation refers to the percentage of children ages 6-59 months old who received at least one high-dose vitamin A capsule in the previous six months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Children's Fund, State of the World's Children.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1,000 women ages 15-19)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adolescent fertility rate is the number of births per 1,000 women ages 15-19.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Completeness of infant death reporting (% of reported infant deaths to estimated infant deaths)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Completeness of infant death reporting is the number of infant deaths reported by national statistics authorities to the United Nations Statistics Division's Demography Yearbook divided by the number of infant deaths estimated by the United Nations Population Division.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The United Nations Statistics Division's Population and Vital Statistics Report and the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Completeness of total death reporting (% of reported total deaths to estimated total deaths)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Completeness of total death reporting is the number of total deaths reported by national statistics authorities to the United Nations Statistics Division's Demography Yearbook divided by the number of total deaths estimated by the United Nations Population Division.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The United Nations Statistics Division's Population and Vital Statistics Report and the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Antenatal care coverage provided by a skilled health provider, at least one visit (%)
Antenatal care coverage provided by any provider (skilled or unskilled), at least four visits (%)
Mortality rate, adult, female (per 1,000 female adults)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adult mortality rate is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is, the probability of a 15-year-old dying before reaching age 60, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates between those ages.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm, (2) University of California, Berkeley, and Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research. Human Mortality Database. [ www.mortality.org or www.human¬mortality.de] downloaded on Dec. 10, 2009.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, adult, male (per 1,000 male adults)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adult mortality rate is the probability of dying between the ages of 15 and 60--that is, the probability of a 15-year-old dying before reaching age 60, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates between those ages.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm, (2) University of California, Berkeley, and Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research. Human Mortality Database. [ www.mortality.org or www.human¬mortality.de] downloaded on Dec. 10, 2009.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Birth rate, crude (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Crude birth rate indicates the number of live births occurring during the year, per 1,000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase, which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables), (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Death rate, crude (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Crude death rate indicates the number of deaths occurring during the year, per 1,000 population estimated at midyear. Subtracting the crude death rate from the crude birth rate provides the rate of natural increase, which is equal to the rate of population change in the absence of migration.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables), (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Contraceptive use among married women 15-49 years old, condom (%)
Contraceptive use among married women 15-49 years old, modern method (%)
Contraceptive prevalence (% of women ages 15-49)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Contraceptive prevalence rate is the percentage of women who are practicing, or whose sexual partners are practicing, any form of contraception. It is usually measured for married women ages 15-49 only.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household surveys, including Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys by UNICEF.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, infant (per 1,000 live births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Infant mortality rate is the number of infants dying before reaching one year of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Level & Trends in Child Mortality. Report 2010. Estimates Developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA, UNPD).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Life expectancy at birth, female (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables), (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Life expectancy at birth, total (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived from male and female life expectancy at birth. Male and female life expectancy source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables), (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Life expectancy at birth, male (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Life expectancy at birth indicates the number of years a newborn infant would live if prevailing patterns of mortality at the time of its birth were to stay the same throughout its life.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables), (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age at first marriage, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age at first marriage shows the mean age at first marriage among those who ever married in the age group 15-50.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World's Women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age at first marriage, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age at first marriage shows the mean age at first marriage among those who ever married in the age group 15-50.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World's Women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fertility rate, total (births per woman)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total fertility rate represents the number of children that would be born to a woman if she were to live to the end of her childbearing years and bear children in accordance with current age-specific fertility rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm. (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database, and (6) household surveys conducted by national agencies, Macro International, and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival to age 65, female (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65, if subject to current age specific mortality rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival to age 65, male (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65, if subject to current age specific mortality rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival to age 65, all (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival to age 65 refers to the percentage of a cohort of newborn infants that would survive to age 65, if subject to current age specific mortality rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wanted fertility rate (births per woman)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wanted fertility rate is an estimate of what the total fertility rate would be if all unwanted births were avoided.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who were first married by age 18 (% of women ages 20-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Women who were first married by age 18 refers to the percentage of women ages 20-24 who were first married by age 18.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teenage mothers (% of women ages 15-19 who have had children or are currently pregnant)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teenage mothers are the percentage of women ages 15-19 who already have children or are currently pregnant.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population ages 0-4, female (% of female population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female population between the ages 0 to 4 as a percentage of the total female population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population ages 0-4, male (% of male population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Male population between the ages 0 to 4 as a percentage of the total male population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population ages 0-14 (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population between the ages 0 to 14 as a percentage of the total population. Population is based on the de facto definition of population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age population, age 25, female, interpolated
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age population, female refers to female population at the specified age level, as estimated by World Bank staff.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, aged 25, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, age 25, female, (UNESCO) is the female population age 25.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age population, age 25, male, interpolated
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age population, male refers to male population at the specified age level, as estimated by World Bank staff.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, aged 25, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, age 25, male, (UNESCO) is the male population age 25.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, aged 25, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, age 25, total, (UNESCO) is the population age 25.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Sex ratio at birth (females per 1,000 males)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Sex ratio at birth refers the number of female live births per 1,000 male live births.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based on United Nations Population Division, World Population Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age dependency ratio (% of working-age population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age dependency ratio is the ratio of dependents--people younger than 15 or older than 64--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age dependency ratio, old (% of working-age population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age dependency ratio, old, is the ratio of older dependents--people older than 64--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Age dependency ratio, young (% of working-age population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Age dependency ratio, young, is the ratio of younger dependents--people younger than 15--to the working-age population--those ages 15-64. Data are shown as the proportion of dependents per 100 working-age population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from various sources including census reports, the United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects, national statistical offices, household surveys conducted by national agencies, and Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Annual population growth rate for year t is the exponential rate of growth of midyear population from year t-1 to t, expressed as a percentage . Population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of the country of origin.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived from total population. Population source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm. (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database, and (6) World bank estimates based on the data from the sources above, household surveys conducted by national agencies, Macro International, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and refugees statistics from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Researchers in R&D (per million people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Researchers in R&D are professionals engaged in the conception or creation of new knowledge, products, processes, methods, or systems and in the management of the projects concerned. Postgraduate PhD students (ISCED97 level 6) engaged in R&D are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Technicians in R&D (per million people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Technicians in R&D and equivalent staff are people whose main tasks require technical knowledge and experience in engineering, physical and life sciences (technicians), or social sciences and humanities (equivalent staff). They participate in R&D by performing scientific and technical tasks involving the application of concepts and operational methods, normally under the supervision of researchers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of their country of origin. The values shown are midyear estimates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm. (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database, and (6) World bank estimates based on the data from the sources above, household surveys conducted by national agencies, Macro International, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and refugees statistics from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, female (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female population is the percentage of the population that is female. Population is based on the de facto definition of population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision. New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables). Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, total (in millions)
wb:indicator.wb:source: International Development Association - Results Measurement System

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population growth (annual %)
Population, pre-primary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, pre-primary, female is the female population of the age group that officially corresponds to pre-primary education.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, primary, male

wb:indicator.wb:name: Completeness of birth registration, rural (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Completeness of birth registration is the percentage of children under age 5 whose births were registered at the time of the survey. The numerator of completeness of birth registration includes children whose birth certificate was seen by the interviewer or whose mother or caretaker says the birth has been registered.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF's State of the World's Children based mostly on household surveys and ministry of health data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Completeness of birth registration, urban (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Completeness of birth registration is the percentage of children under age 5 whose births were registered at the time of the survey. The numerator of completeness of birth registration includes children whose birth certificate was seen by the interviewer or whose mother or caretaker says the birth has been registered.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF's State of the World's Children based mostly on household surveys and ministry of health data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Completeness of birth registration (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Completeness of birth registration is the percentage of children under age 5 whose births were registered at the time of the survey. The numerator of completeness of birth registration includes children whose birth certificate was seen by the interviewer or whose mother or caretaker says the birth has been registered.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF's State of the World's Children based mostly on household surveys and ministry of health data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rural population
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the difference between total population and urban population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: The data on urban population shares used to estimate rural population come from the United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects. Total population figures are World Bank estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rural population growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the difference between total population and urban population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rural population (% of total population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the difference between total population and urban population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, low secondary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, lower secondary, female is the female population of the age group that officially corresponds to lower secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, lower secondary, total is the total population of the age group that officially corresponds to lower secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, secondary, total is the total population of the age group that officially corresponds to secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, secondary, male

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, upper secondary, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, upper secondary, total is the total population of the age group that officially corresponds to upper secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, upper secondary, male

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, tertiary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, tertiary, female is the female population of the age group that officially corresponds to tertiary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, tertiary, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, tertiary, total is the total population of the age group that officially corresponds to tertiary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Population, tertiary, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Population, tertiary, male is the male population of the age group that officially corresponds to tertiary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban population growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban population
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank Staff estimates based on United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urban population (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World Urbanization Prospects.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unmet need for contraception (% of married women ages 15-49)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unmet need for contraception is the percentage of fertile, married women of reproductive age who do not want to become pregnant and are not using contraception.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household surveys, including Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys by UNICEF.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Water supply failure for firms receiving water (average days/year)
International tourism, number of arrivals
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International inbound tourists (overnight visitors) are the number of tourists who travel to a country other than that in which they have their usual residence, but outside their usual environment, for a period not exceeding 12 months and whose main purpose in visiting is other than an activity remunerated from within the country visited. When data on number of tourists are not available, the number of visitors, which includes tourists, same-day visitors, cruise passengers, and crew members, is shown instead. Sources and collection methods for arrivals differ across countries. In some cases data are from border statistics (police, immigration, and the like) and supplemented by border surveys. In other cases data are from tourism accommodation establishments. For some countries number of arrivals is limited to arrivals by air and for others to arrivals staying in hotels. Some countries include arrivals of nationals residing abroad while others do not. Caution should thus be used in comparing arrivals across countries. The data on inbound tourists refer to the number of arrivals, not to the number of people traveling. Thus a person who makes several trips to a country during a given period is counted each time as a new arrival.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, number of departures
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International outbound tourists are the number of departures that people make from their country of usual residence to any other country for any purpose other than a remunerated activity in the country visited. The data on outbound tourists refer to the number of departures, not to the number of people traveling. Thus a person who makes several trips from a country during a given period is counted each time as a new departure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, receipts (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism receipts are expenditures by international inbound visitors, including payments to national carriers for international transport. These receipts include any other prepayment made for goods or services received in the destination country. They also may include receipts from same-day visitors, except when these are important enough to justify separate classification. For some countries they do not include receipts for passenger transport items. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, receipts (% of total exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism receipts are expenditures by international inbound visitors, including payments to national carriers for international transport. These receipts include any other prepayment made for goods or services received in the destination country. They also may include receipts from same-day visitors, except when these are important enough to justify separate classification. For some countries they do not include receipts for passenger transport items. Their share in exports is calculated as a ratio to exports of goods and services, which comprise all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world involving a change of ownership from residents to nonresidents of general merchandise, goods sent for processing and repairs, nonmonetary gold, and services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files, and IMF and World Bank exports estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, receipts for passenger transport items (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism receipts for passenger transport items are expenditures by international inbound visitors for all services provided in the international transportation by resident carriers. Also included are passenger services performed within an economy by nonresident carriers. Excluded are passenger services provided to nonresidents by resident carriers within the resident economies; these are included in travel items. In addition to the services covered by passenger fares--including fares that are a part of package tours but excluding cruise fares, which are included in travel--passenger services include such items as charges for excess baggage, vehicles, or other personal accompanying effects and expenditures for food, drink, or other items for which passengers make expenditures while on board carriers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, expenditures for passenger transport items (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism expenditures for passenger transport items are expenditures of international outbound visitors in other countries for all services provided during international transportation by nonresident carriers. Also included are passenger services performed within an economy by nonresident carriers. Excluded are passenger services provided to nonresidents by resident carriers within the resident economies; these are included in travel items. In addition to the services covered by passenger fares--including fares that are a part of package tours but excluding cruise fares, which are included in travel--passenger services include such items as charges for excess baggage, vehicles, or other personal accompanying effects and expenditures for food, drink, or other items for which passengers make expenditures while on board carriers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, receipts for travel items (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism receipts for travel items are expenditures by international inbound visitors in the reporting economy. The goods and services are purchased by, or on behalf of, the traveler or provided, without a quid pro quo, for the traveler to use or give away. These receipts should include any other prepayment made for goods or services received in the destination country. They also may include receipts from same-day visitors, except in cases where these are so important as to justify a separate classification. Excluded is the international carriage of travelers, which is covered in passenger travel items. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, expenditures for travel items (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism expenditures are expenditures of international outbound visitors in other countries. The goods and services are purchased by, or on behalf of, the traveler or provided, without a quid pro quo, for the traveler to use or give away. These may include expenditures by residents traveling abroad as same-day visitors, except in cases where these are so important as to justify a separate classification. Excluded is the international carriage of travelers, which is covered in passenger travel items. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, expenditures (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism expenditures are expenditures of international outbound visitors in other countries, including payments to foreign carriers for international transport. These expenditures may include those by residents traveling abroad as same-day visitors, except in cases where these are important enough to justify separate classification. For some countries they do not include expenditures for passenger transport items. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International tourism, expenditures (% of total imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International tourism expenditures are expenditures of international outbound visitors in other countries, including payments to foreign carriers for international transport. These expenditures may include those by residents traveling abroad as same-day visitors, except in cases where these are important enough to justify separate classification. For some countries they do not include expenditures for passenger transport items. Their share in imports is calculated as a ratio to imports of goods and services, which comprise all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world involving a change of ownership from nonresidents to residents of general merchandise, goods sent for processing and repairs, nonmonetary gold, and services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Tourism Organization, Yearbook of Tourism Statistics, Compendium of Tourism Statistics and data files, and IMF and World Bank imports estimates.
